philosophers_schema.name: Laozi
philosophers_schema.description: Known as the author of Daodejing (also known as 'The Classic of the Way and of Virtue'). His idea in Chinese is called Wu Wei (means 'inaction'). By 'inaction' however it doesn't necessarily mean not doing any actions, but to do in bare minimum needed until the rest is done spontaneously.

philosophers_schema.name: Confucius
philosophers_schema.description: Known as the most impactful teacher in the whole history of China. He is the author of Analects, which not only includes his teachings, but also how to teach. Ren and Zhi are two fundamental virtues of Confucianism.

philosophers_schema.name: Siddhartha Gautama (Buddha)
philosophers_schema.description: Buddha means 'Awakened One', or 'Enlightened One'. His teaching was to overcome Dukkha ('pain' or 'dissatisfaction') with everyday life.

philosophers_schema.name: Diotima of Mantinea
philosophers_schema.description: She was inspiring to Socrates, and gave the basics of the 'Platonic love' concept (love without sexual desires) to Plato.

philosophers_schema.name: Socrates
philosophers_schema.description: Socrates is described as 'The Gadfly of Athens' by Plato. He tried to understand basic human concerns like ethics, justice, and virtue.

philosophers_schema.name: Diogenes of Sinope
philosophers_schema.description: Diogenes is famous for challenging traditions in a violent and insulting way, and the austerity and simplicity of his life based on his Cynic philosophy.

philosophers_schema.name: Plato
philosophers_schema.description: Plato is one of the most impactful philosophers in western philosophy. He was a notable student of Socrates and documented his legal self-defense in the Apology of Socrates.

philosophers_schema.name: Aristotle
philosophers_schema.description: Unlike his teacher Plato, Aristotle had a natural approach in philosophy. He was interested in biology, especially studying sea creatures.

philosophers_schema.name: Mencius
philosophers_schema.description: Mencius, also known as Mengzi, is one of the most notable Confucianist philosophers. He believed that human nature is righteous and humane.

philosophers_schema.name: Master Zhuang
philosophers_schema.description: He had a simple life in nature far from society, which was consistent with his Taoist beliefs. He is the author of Zhuangzi.

philosophers_schema.name: Epicurus
philosophers_schema.description: Epicurus's Liberal Materialism is often misinterpreted as the symbol of extreme hedonism. He believed that the goal of life is to live happily and with pleasure.

philosophers_schema.name: Marcus Aurelius
philosophers_schema.description: He was a Stoic philosopher who became the Roman emperor at the age of 40. He is the author of the 'Meditations'.

philosophers_schema.name: Nagarjuna
philosophers_schema.description: He is one of the most important and impactful Buddhist philosophers. He is the founder of Madhyamaka or 'The Middle Way' school.

philosophers_schema.name: Augustine of Hippo
philosophers_schema.description: He was a theologian and philosopher of Berber origin. He was against slavery and boldly wrote a letter urging the emperor to set up a new law against slave traders.

philosophers_schema.name: Hypatia
philosophers_schema.description: She was the most famous astronomer and mathematician of her time, as well as a prominent Neoplatonic teacher and philosopher.

philosophers_schema.name: Boethius
philosophers_schema.description: Boethius is one of the greatest philosophers of the classical period. In prison, he wrote his masterpiece 'On the Consolation of Philosophy'.

philosophers_schema.name: Ibn Sina (Avicenna)
philosophers_schema.description: Ibn Sina is the polymath author of 'The Book of Healing' and 'The Canon of Medicine' encyclopedias.

philosophers_schema.name: Anselm
philosophers_schema.description: Known as the father of the scholastic tradition, Anselm was the philosopher monk of Canterbury.

philosophers_schema.name: Hildegard of Bingen
philosophers_schema.description: Known as 'The Sibyl of the Rhine', she was one of the most impactful composer, philosopher, mystic, visionary, and a medical writer of the Middle Ages.

philosophers_schema.name: Héloïse
philosophers_schema.description: Writer, philosopher of love and friendship, and the French nun, Héloïse, was one of the pioneers of the feminist thought.

philosophers_schema.name: Ibn Rushd (Averroes)
philosophers_schema.description: He combined Greek and Islamic thoughts. His philosophical works include numerous commentaries on Aristotle.

philosophers_schema.name: Zhu Xi
philosophers_schema.description: He created an impactful philosophical system known as Neo-Confucianism.

philosophers_schema.name: Moses Maimonides
philosophers_schema.description: Maimonides was the physician, the lawyer, and the philosopher who first adapted Aristotle's teachings to Jewish theology.

philosophers_schema.name: Albertus Magnus
philosophers_schema.description: Known as the 'Doctor Universalis' because of the vast of his knowledge. He combined Aristotle's thoughts with Christian teachings.

philosophers_schema.name: Thomas Aquinas
philosophers_schema.description: He was an Italian Dominican friar and priest, and known as the most influential thinker of the Middle Ages.

philosophers_schema.name: William of Ockham
philosophers_schema.description: He believed that God cannot be known directly, and God will always be incomprehensible to mankind.

philosophers_schema.name: Desiderius Erasmus
philosophers_schema.description: He was a Humanist philosopher. His most famous book is the 'In praise of Folly'.

philosophers_schema.name: Niccolo Machiavelli
philosophers_schema.description: He is most notably known for 'The Prince' book. He advises an imaginary prince about statecraft and politics.

philosophers_schema.name: Michel de Montaigne
philosophers_schema.description: He was one of the most significant philosophers of the French Renaissance. He popularized essay-writing as a literary genre.

philosophers_schema.name: Francis Bacon
philosophers_schema.description: Known as the father of empiricism. He was the first philosopher to use a post-Aristotelian method for empirical research.

philosophers_schema.name: Thomas Hobbes
philosophers_schema.description: He was famous for his political philosophy in his book 'Leviathan', and a radical and pessimistic materialist.

philosophers_schema.name: René Descartes
philosophers_schema.description: Cogito ergo sum (I think, therefore I am). René Descartes is known as the father of modern philosophy.

philosophers_schema.name: Blaise Pascal
philosophers_schema.description: He was an extraordinary talented person in the field of mathematics to practical inventions, however, his focus was on his spiritual quest.

philosophers_schema.name: Baruch Spinoza
philosophers_schema.description: He studied the philosophy of the philosophers who came before him. He could not accept the absolute distinction between mind and body.

philosophers_schema.name: John Locke
philosophers_schema.description: John Locke's works established the basis of political liberalism and philosophical empiricism.

philosophers_schema.name: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
philosophers_schema.description: Known as the Aristotle of the modern world, he was a thinker who wanted to fill the gap between the God-centered world and the rationalism caused by the scientific revolution.

philosophers_schema.name: Juana Inés de la Cruz
philosophers_schema.description: She was a poet, scholar, dramatist, and a nun who devoted her life to scientific and philosophical studies.

philosophers_schema.name: George Berkeley
philosophers_schema.description: He was a priest and philosopher who proposed the concept of Subjective Idealism and believed that material objects exist only in the form of perception.

philosophers_schema.name: Voltaire
philosophers_schema.description: Voltaire was one of the key figures of the rationalism of the Age of Enlightenment and one of the founders of the modern liberal tradition.
